properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday midday and persist through Thursday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible Wednesday night with an additional 5 centimetres possible Thursday before the squalls move out of the area. Snow squall warnings will likely be required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T19:10:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T03:11:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1642366473.2019
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls on Wednesday. The squalls could start as early as Wednesday morning and are expected to continue through Wednesday night. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible on Wednesday, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T19:05:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T03:06:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1171444919.2019
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for tonight. Lake effect snow bands may affect areas well inland from Lake Huron tonight with 2 to 5 cm possible. Travel may be impacted due to accumulating snow and low visibility in heavy snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Lakes Within Whiteshell Provincial Park
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the lakes within the Whiteshell Provincial Park area due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as levels as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing water or waters of unknown depth. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-13T16:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-12T15:44:17-06:00, 896F67B0-0615-F789-C793-CF64A28F5BE3
Area: Whiteshell Provincial Park
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Summary:

Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Stuartburn due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain will continue across the Island until late overnight tonight. Total rainfall accumulations up to 25 millimetres are forecast, although it is possible that higher amounts may fall in localized areas. The rain is expected to change to flurries before Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult as the cold air and flurries move in. A snow squall watch has been issued for eastern regions of the Island for Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero will also be a concern. The local snow squalls are forecast to come to an end when the winds shift to southwest later Wednesday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain will continue across Nova Scotia tonight, then change to flurries overnight or Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Total rainfall accumulations are expected to be quite variable, with forecast amounts ranging from 30 to 65 mm and locally higher amounts possible along parts of the Atlantic coast. Driving conditions may become difficult overnight or Wednesday morning as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h on Wednesday giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest Wednesday night, with local gusts of 110 km/h expected, causing blizzard like conditions. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T18:06:57-00:00

Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter weather travel advisory in effect for tonight. Lake effect snow bands will affect areas southeast of Georgian Bay into Wednesday morning. Travel may be impacted due to accumulating snow, particularly during the evening commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow is expected to taper to scattered flurries later this evening. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain is forecast to continue until early Wednesday morning, with total forecast rainfall accumulations ranging from 40 to 60 millimetres over the region. Rain is expected to change to flurries early on Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move across the province. Flurries will persist through the day on Wednesday and into Wednesday night, when conditions will become favourable for the development of snow squalls. A snow squall watch has been issued for Wednesday night. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T16:59:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T02:18:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3192634869.2019
Area: Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls weakening tonight. Flurries and snow squalls are forecast to move westward and retreat towards Georgian Bay tonight. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm remain possible. Locations impacted include: Keswick, Georgina and Sutton. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero will also be a concern until the snow squalls end. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T09:59:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T02:53:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3959129914.2019
Area: Newmarket - Georgina - Northern York Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday morning and persist through the day. Local snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm will be possible by Wednesday evening when the snow squalls are forecast to move east of the region. A snow squall warning may be required. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T19:07:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T03:08:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2390924033.2019

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog over the 100 Mile region will persist through tonight. The fog is expected to dissipate Wednesday morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday midday and persist through Thursday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible Wednesday night with an additional 5 centimetres possible Thursday before the squalls move out of the area. Snow squall warnings will likely be required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
